Description: Terracotta figure of Ptah. Ptah is depicted crouching, with hands on his ribbed stomach. Hair has moulded design of horizontal bands. From two-piece mould. Partially reconstructed from fragments, feet missing and stained black (possibly slip) on shoulder and hair on back. Pale buff clay with orange patches and common fine silver mica and black inclusions.
Curator's comments: Closed parallel (possibly same mould) from Rhodes dated second half of 6th century BC (Mollard-Besques 1954, 38, B221). There are also close parallels in the British Museum of the same pale orange mica rich fabric and dated late 6th century BC from Melos (GR1842,0728.754), Gela, Sicily (GR1863,0728.280), unprovenanced (GR1926,0324.13) and with monkey from Melos (GR1842,0728.756). Chemical analysis (NAA), suggests a Samian origin. Mollard-Besques, S. 1954. Catalogue raisonnédes figurines et reliefs en terre-cuite Grecs Étrusques et Romains I: Époques Préhellénique Géométrique, Archaïque et Classique. Paris: Musée National du Louvre.
Bibliographic references: Terracotta / Catalogue of Terracottas in the British Museum (92)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (DB.056) (Phase 1)
